channel.title: RuneScape News
channel.description:
"Today we have made an adjustment to rune essence mining due to players breaking rule 7 and rule 12, using macros to mine the rune essence and then sell it.
As you are probably aware we have various systems in place to detect people breaking rule 7 and ban them. These systems work very effectively at detecting people breaking this rule, and make macroing a really bad way to try and train a high level character.
The problem we are now solving is not a problem with our macro detection systems which are still working well, but rather a problem with banning being an ineffective punishment against abusers who only use very low level accounts, and who have no intention of ever playing the game properly.
Over the last few weeks we have banned literally hundreds of accounts a day for macroing at the rune essence mine. However the bans were ineffective as the abusers could just create more low level accounts that they didn't care about to mine more. We also track trades so we can ban the recipiant of the illegally obtained items, but the abusers in this case were swapping the runes for gp, and then selling the gp for real world money on auction sites. Of course the person buying the gp for real world money gets banned, because we track the money they received in an unbalanced trade to a macro account, but the seller doesn't care that their customers get banned shortly after, as they have their real world money by then.
The fundamental problem is that rune essence was one of the few areas of the game which could be used to generate a reasonable amount of RuneScape money on a 'throwaway' low level free account. Normally to earn large amounts of money quickly you need to level up an account first, and then of course you care if it gets banned so our normal deterrent is effective. " -From runescape.com
I'm glad Jagex finally realizes what cheaters have been doing for years (Make account - auto - trade to mule - sell for rl money). I'm not sure if this was a wise move, though. Most human being are eager by nature and this kind of opportunity (making real life cash out of game) could be too much for a legal player and he/she might jump in the cheaters camp and start searching for macros.
Enough of BS, lets get to the point: Is it possible for Jagex to detect if the GP is autoed after the money has passed from person to person? Ofcourse, it is technically possible but does Jagex really trace the RS GP? I find it quite hard to believe and I'd like to hear your opinions on it.

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

im sure they can track but as mopar said it only flags high amounts however mopar i dont think killing yourself in the wild with high amounts of stuff will go unnoticed i dont think they moniter just high amounts of items in trades but rather accounts with high amounts of items the code was allready introduced in private servers by xerocheez

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:

Hah, I could see this game turning into all members. Shh, don't tell Jagex that they could do so much to ruin us.

item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

In a way we're destroying their game, in a way we're forcing it to evolve into a better more balanced game, or forcing them to make everything good members.

item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:

http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=crack-a-lackin

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Look fools.

Each player has a UID serverside that identifies them, no one is known by their actual username. Did you know that? Oh didn't think so.

Anyways the client has a converter between the two UID and USERNAME... What if they just identify cheating accounts and put their UID on everything that passes through them. 1 long on an item doesnt take much data at all. And then you're banned.

Maybe stop using aryan, the intensive care unit of botting. (Thanks krichevskoy :laugh:) And stop heeding none of my advice, or krich's advice. I think you'd be rudely surprised.

Peace...

Sorry if I came off rude in this reply, I'm rushed.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Freddy1990:

this actually means that we are undirectly destroying the game ^^ altough jagex is doing the actual destroying, lol

The perfect crime

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Ahaha rofl this is hilarious. They just ruined the free version for a lot of people. Without ess I would have never suvived in that game when I first started.

Newest news:
It has been brought to our attention that some free users who used to be members have had their essence converted into pure essence they can't use. Don't worry, we are aware of this and are working to fix it.

Read full topic

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

moparisthebest:

[quote author=pplsuqbawlz link=topic=1676.msg15541#msg15541 date=1145556707]
I've been saying this for sooo long. Thanks for listening to me guys. Onnnnce again.

where did you say it? I never saw it anywhere :P[/quote]

What, that large trades for nothing are suspicious? Obvious much?
Anyway, if you don't have the initiative to launder your gp then I guess you'll just get caught. I imagine a massive bot-run network of characters trading small amounts of gp for newb items and eventually funnelling the full amount to the intended recipient (over the course of, say, two days to a week depending on the amount). Most people aren't that patient, but I'd love to write those scripts sometime, run it as a service...
Anyway, I've always assumed that there are tons of "rule-breaker" flags on your char data serverside, marking suspicious activity and such. Could easily be a "LARGE NULL TRADE" alert, and if your character has been marked for something else as well then you're screwed.

Read full topic

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

As far as I know, Items etc. are just numbers to the server, so logically each item would have it's own UID which could be traced.
Fuck knows if they actually do it, it's another one of those unanswerable questions

Read full topic

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

moparisthebest:

If they actually had a seperate item id for each gp then yes they could track it, but the client puts them in the same stacks, and uses the same item id, so its just not possible imho

Acutally, right there you just made an amazing point. There really isn't any way that they could do that.

Unless, somehow, they can have a sub-id. I don't see that as being possible either, though.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:

They don't seem to get that we aren't stupid...

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest

@moparisthebest wrote:

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Would they be able to track the gp over 10+ trades? I think it'd get to jumbled up and there efforts would be useless.

Read full topic

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @kmb Kmb
item.description:
@kmb wrote:

moparisthebest:

...
but no, there is no way they could track specific gp, just trades and the like, because to track specific gp it would all have to have a different item id, and since we decompile the client, we know that it doesnt

But for all we know, the client is just drawing the graphics, and as Andrew himself has once said (something like): "The client is about 10% of the code, server is 90%".

Could Jagex somehow mark the autoed money and after every trade the server would check if the gp is marked, and if a large amount os this marked money is being traded for nothing between the same IP, they would give you a free trip to the banana isle.
I doubt it but someone beyond my knowledge could probaly enlighten me if this is possible and do they actually do this.

Read full topic

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

I'm almost died laughing after seeing this.

Even though a ton of people go for ess, but that is the least of thier problems.

They also come out with new randoms which makes absolutely no sense. We can create anti-randoms for everything with java bots, but they're to stupid to realize that I'm guessing.

And Mopar, I've been doing that the whole time (killing neebs).

Read full topic

item.title: RuneScape News
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

kmb:

I'm glad Jagex finally realizes what cheaters have been doing for years (Make account - auto - trade to mule - sell for rl money). I'm not sure if this was a wise move, though. Most human being are eager by nature and this kind of opportunity (making real life cash out of game) could be too much for a legal player and he/she might jump in the cheaters camp and start searching for macros.

Enough of BS, lets get to the point: Is it possible for Jagex to detect if the GP is autoed after the money has passed from person to person? Ofcourse, it is technically possible but does Jagex really trace the RS GP? I find it quite hard to believe and I'd like to hear your opinions on it.

No Jagex is blowing smoke up people's asses when they say they can "track dirty money" as they put it, obviously it would be easy to write some serverside code that detects a high amount of somthing (or money) being traded for nothing or a low amount of somthing, it could be done in 5 lines or less, If/when I start botting again the way I will trade will be undetectable, I will simply trade all of my botted goods to one bot account, then log in with my mule/main account (the bots will always be using a proxy) and kill the bot account with all my stuff on it out in the wildy, pick up my stuff and go home

but no, there is no way they could track specific gp, just trades and the like, because to track specific gp it would all have to have a different item id, and since we decompile the client, we know that it doesnt

Read full topic
